I posted this question half a year ago. The answer that I received 
was to use a decorator. It works this way. But I cannot execute a 
test with its decorator in Eclipse. So I cannot use it.

Here is the bug report which I posted at the Eclipse site. Its bug 
76232. Since I didn't receive any answer there, I post it here. I 
hope someone can help me.



I want to perform something before the tests start. After all tests 
of a class have finished I want to perform another thing. Overwriting 
tearDown does not work for this requirement, it is called too often 
by JUnit. When the last test has finished I want to perform 
something. But it needs to be within JUnit, not outside of it.

I've coded something like this in the main method to solve the 
problem:
TestDecorator myTestSetup = new MyTestSetup(new SupplierArticleTest
("testInitialValidation"));
junit.textui.TestRunner.run(myTestSetup);

It works but it doesn't work in the Eclipse JUnit view. It should 
work in the JUnit view. Can I decorate a test and start it with its 
decoration in the Eclipse JUnit view? Or is there another solution 
for my problem?

The most straightforward thing would have been if I had two 
additional methods in the TestCase: setUpTestCase() and 
tearDownTestCase(). Both would be called only once, the first, when 
the test (all test methods in a TestCase) starts and the last when 
the test ends (all test methods in a TestCase).
